| 35 | ‚Çπ13,500 | ‚Çπ26,500 | +96% |
| 40 | ‚Çπ20,500 | ‚Çπ42,000 | +105% |

**Key insight:** Smokers pay nearly **double** the premium. This includes tobacco chewers (gutkha, paan) too. If you've quit smoking for 12+ months, some insurers offer non-smoker rates after verification.

---

## Cover Till 60 vs 65 vs 70 vs 75

| Entry Age 30 | Till 60 | Till 65 | Till 70 | Till 75 |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Annual Premium | ‚Çπ9,500 | ‚Çπ11,200 | ‚Çπ14,500 | ‚Çπ19,000 |
| Total Paid | ‚Çπ2,85,000 | ‚Çπ3,92,000 | ‚Çπ5,80,000 | ‚Çπ8,55,000 |
| Premium increase | Base | +18% | +53% | +100% |

**When to choose longer tenure:**
- Dependents are young (will need support past your 60)
- Home loan EMI extends beyond 60
- You plan to work/earn till 65+

Read: [Tenure guide](/resources/term-insurance/tenure)

---

## Premium by Sum Assured (Age 30, Male, Non-Smoker, Till 60)

| Cover Amount | Annual Premium | Cost per ‚Çπ1 Lakh Cover |
|---|---|---|
| ‚Çπ50 Lakhs | ‚Çπ5,800 | ‚Çπ11.60 |
| ‚Çπ75 Lakhs | ‚Çπ7,500 | ‚Çπ10.00 |
| ‚Çπ1 Crore | ‚Çπ9,500 | ‚Çπ9.50 |
| ‚Çπ1.5 Crore | ‚Çπ13,000 | ‚Çπ8.67 |
| ‚Çπ2 Crore | ‚Çπ16,500 | ‚Çπ8.25 |
| ‚Çπ3 Crore | ‚Çπ23,000 | ‚Çπ7.67 |

**Key insight:** Higher cover = better per-lakh cost. Don't under-buy to save small premiums.

---

## The Real Cost of Waiting (Age Impact)

### Scenario: ‚Çπ1 Cr cover till age 60

| Buy at age | Annual Premium | Years of payment | Total Paid |
|---|---|---|---|
| 25 | ‚Çπ7,100 | 35 years | ‚Çπ2,48,500 |
| 30 | ‚Çπ9,500 | 30 years | ‚Çπ2,85,000 |
| 35 | ‚Çπ13,500 | 25 years | ‚Çπ3,37,500 |
| 40 | ‚Çπ20,500 | 20 years | ‚Çπ4,10,000 |

**Cost of 5-year delay (25 ‚Üí 30):** ‚Çπ36,500 extra lifetime premium
**Cost of 10-year delay (25 ‚Üí 35):** ‚Çπ89,000 extra lifetime premium
**Cost of 15-year delay (25 ‚Üí 40):** ‚Çπ1,61,500 extra lifetime premium

Plus, health issues can develop, making you uninsurable or pushing you to higher rates.

---

## Payment Frequency Options

| Frequency | Annual Equivalent | Extra Cost |
|---|---|---|
| Annual | ‚Çπ9,500 | Base |
| Semi-annual | ‚Çπ9,880 | +4% |
| Quarterly | ‚Çπ10,070 | +6% |
| Monthly | ‚Çπ10,260 | +8% |

**Recommendation:** Pay annually if cash flow allows‚Äîsaves 6-8% over monthly payments.

---

## What affects your premium? (Beyond age)

| Factor | Impact on Premium |
|---|---|
| Smoking/tobacco | +80-110% |
| BMI (overweight) | +10-30% |
| Family history (heart disease, cancer) | +10-25% |
| Hazardous occupation | +15-40% |
| Adventure sports (regular) | +5-15% |
| Pre-existing conditions | +20-50% or decline |
| City tier | Minimal (1-3%) |

---

## How to get the best rate

1. **Buy young:** Every year you wait, premium increases ~8-12%
2. **Declare honestly:** Wrong declarations = claim rejection, not savings
3. **Compare 3-4 insurers:** Same profile can have 15-20% premium difference
4. **Pay annually:** Saves 6-8% vs monthly
5. **Skip unnecessary riders:** Each rider adds 5-15% to premium
6. **Maintain health:** Some insurers offer wellness discounts

- **No spam:** we don't sell your data; we keep advice simple and actionable.

- **Kshitij Jain (Co-Founder):** Ex-BCG consultant; IIM Ahmedabad & IIT Delhi alumnus.

## FAQs

### Is ‚Çπ1 crore term insurance enough for me?
It depends on your liabilities, dependents, and income. Metro families with home loans often need ‚Çπ1.5-2 Cr minimum. Use [how much cover calculator](/resources/term-insurance/how-much-cover).

### Why do women pay less for term insurance?
Women have longer life expectancy statistically. Lower mortality risk = lower premiums. Difference is typically 20-30% lower than men.

### Can I get ‚Çπ1 crore cover if I'm 50?
Yes, but premiums will be high (‚Çπ50,000+/year). Medical underwriting may be strict. Some insurers cap entry age at 55-60.

### Will my premium increase every year?
No. Term insurance premiums are locked at purchase. You pay the same amount throughout the policy term.

### Is monthly payment better than annual?
Annual is cheaper (saves 6-8%). Monthly is easier on cash flow. Choose based on your budget discipline.

### How does smoking affect term insurance premium?
Smokers pay 80-110% more. This includes cigarettes, bidi, gutkha, vaping. If you quit for 12+ months, some insurers offer non-smoker rates.

### Can I increase my cover later?
Some policies allow cover increase at life events (marriage, child birth). Or you can buy an additional policy (with fresh underwriting at current age).

### What if I can't afford ‚Çπ1 crore cover?
Buy what you can afford now, but ensure it covers at least your liabilities. You can increase later. Some cover is better than no cover.

### Are online term insurance premiums lower?
Yes, typically 5-15% lower than offline plans. Same company, same claim process‚Äîjust no agent commission built in.

### Do premiums differ between insurers for same cover?
Yes, by 10-20% for same profile. That's why comparing 3-4 insurers is worth the effort.

### Is it better to buy two ‚Çπ50L policies or one ‚Çπ1Cr?
One ‚Çπ1Cr policy is usually cheaper (per-lakh cost decreases with higher cover) and simpler for claims.

### What's the cheapest ‚Çπ1 crore term plan?
SBI Life eShield and ICICI iProtect are often among the cheapest. But don't choose purely on premium‚Äîcheck claim ratios too.

It depends on your liabilities, dependents, and income. Metro families with home loans often need ‚Çπ1.5-2 Cr minimum. Use [how much cover calculator](/resources/term-insurance/how-much-cover).

### Why do women pay less for term insurance?
Women have longer life expectancy statistically. Lower mortality risk = lower premiums. Difference is typically 20-30% lower than men.

### Can I get ‚Çπ1 crore cover if I'm 50?
Yes, but premiums will be high (‚Çπ50,000+/year). Medical underwriting may be strict. Some insurers cap entry age at 55-60.

### Will my premium increase every year?
No. Term insurance premiums are locked at purchase. You pay the same amount throughout the policy term.

### Is monthly payment better than annual?
Annual is cheaper (saves 6-8%). Monthly is easier on cash flow. Choose based on your budget discipline.

### How does smoking affect term insurance premium?
Smokers pay 80-110% more. This includes cigarettes, bidi, gutkha, vaping. If you quit for 12+ months, some insurers offer non-smoker rates.

### Can I increase my cover later?
Some policies allow cover increase at life events (marriage, child birth). Or you can buy an additional policy (with fresh underwriting at current age).

### What if I can't afford ‚Çπ1 crore cover?
Buy what you can afford now, but ensure it covers at least your liabilities. You can increase later. Some cover is better than no cover.

### Are online term insurance premiums lower?
Yes, typically 5-15% lower than offline plans. Same company, same claim process‚Äîjust no agent commission built in.

Yes, by 10-20% for same profile. That's why comparing 3-4 insurers is worth the effort.

One ‚Çπ1Cr policy is usually cheaper (per-lakh cost decreases with higher cover) and simpler for claims.

SBI Life eShield and ICICI iProtect are often among the cheapest. But don't choose purely on premium‚Äîcheck claim ratios too.

### Which is the best term insurance in India 2026?
Max Life Smart Secure Plus has the highest claim settlement ratio (99.51%) among private insurers. LIC Tech Term has government backing. Choose based on your priorities.

### Is LIC term insurance better than private insurers?
LIC has government backing and high trust. But private insurers like Max Life have better claim ratios. Both are safe choices.

### What is a good claim settlement ratio?
Above 97% is acceptable. Above 98% is good. Above 99% is excellent. Always check 3-year trends, not just one year.

### Should I buy term insurance online or through an agent?
Online plans are typically 5-10% cheaper. Agents can help with complex situations. Either way, disclosure and documentation matter more.

### Why are some term plans cheaper than others?
Pricing depends on company's mortality experience, operating costs, investment returns, and marketing strategy. Cheaper isn't always better if claims suffer.

### Can I trust claim settlement ratios?
They're published by IRDAI, so reliable. But check "claim amount settlement ratio" too‚Äîsome insurers settle many small claims but contest large ones.

Depends on your liabilities and dependents. For metro families with home loans, ‚Çπ1Cr may be minimum. Use the [cover calculator](/resources/term-insurance/how-much-cover).

### Should I split cover between two insurers?
Not usually necessary. One good policy is simpler for claims. Some high-net-worth individuals split for diversification.

### How often do insurers change their claim ratios?
Ratios change yearly. A consistent track record (3+ years) matters more than one exceptional year.

### Are online-only term plans safe?
Yes, they're backed by the same insurer. Online plans often have cleaner terms and lower costs.

### What riders should I add?
Consider: accidental death benefit, waiver of premium on disability. Avoid complex critical illness riders unless you understand every condition. See [Riders explained](/resources/term-insurance/riders).

### Can I switch insurers if I'm unhappy?
You can buy a new policy but can't transfer an existing one. Medical underwriting will apply at your current age.

---

## The 30-second answer
A good term cover is typically **(all liabilities) + (10‚Äì15 years of expenses/income gap) + (big goals like children‚Äôs education)** minus existing liquid assets and existing life cover. The goal is to ensure your family can **repay loans and maintain lifestyle** without being forced to sell assets quickly.

**Back to:** [Term Insurance guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Goal:** make sure your family gets a clean payout if you‚Äôre not around.
- **Avoid:** hiding medical/tobacco history, choosing too-short tenure, and messy nomination.
- **Prefer:** a simple plan, right cover + tenure, and honest disclosures (even for occasional tobacco).
- **Claims-first:** keep policy PDF, premium receipts, nominee KYC, and insurer contact details handy.

---

## Quick calculation table (fill this once)
| Component | How to estimate | Amount (‚Çπ) |
|---|---|---|
| A) Home loan + other loans | Outstanding principal |  |
| B) Annual family expense | Current monthly expense √ó 12 |  |
| C) Income replacement years | Usually 10‚Äì15 years |  |
| D) Big goals | Education, marriage, dependent parents |  |
| E) Existing liquid assets | FD, mutual funds, cash (not primary home) | (‚Äì) |
| F) Existing life cover | Employer term, other term plans | (‚Äì) |
| **Recommended cover** | A + (B√óC) + D ‚Äì E ‚Äì F |  |

---

## Step-by-step: choosing the right cover
### 1) Clear liabilities first
Your family shouldn‚Äôt inherit your EMIs. Start with:
- Home loan
- Personal loans/credit cards
- Business loans (if family is responsible)

### 2) Replace income (or expenses)
A practical approach is expenses-based:
- Estimate current monthly expenses
- Multiply by 12
- Multiply by 10‚Äì15 years (more if kids are young)

### 3) Add goal-based buffers
Common big-ticket goals:
- Children‚Äôs education (India + abroad)
- Special needs dependent care
- Parent medical support (if they rely on you)

### 4) Subtract assets carefully
Subtract liquid, accessible assets. Don‚Äôt count:
- Your primary residence (family still needs it)
- Illiquid assets that take time to sell

---

## How tenure and cover interact
If you choose a shorter tenure, you may need higher cover (less time to build assets). Tenure guide: [Term insurance tenure](/resources/term-insurance/tenure)

---

## Common mistakes
- Buying ‚Äú10√ó salary‚Äù blindly without considering liabilities and expenses
- Underestimating inflation for goals
- Assuming employer cover is permanent
- Choosing cover based on premium comfort instead of need

## FAQs
### Is 1 crore term insurance enough?
It depends on your liabilities and family expenses. For many metro families with home loans, ‚Çπ1Cr may be the minimum starting point.

### Should I use salary multiple or expense method?
Use liabilities + expense replacement + goals. Salary multiples are rough shortcuts.

### Should both spouses buy term insurance?
If both contribute income or care responsibilities, often yes.

### Do I need term insurance if I have no loans?
If you have dependents who rely on your income, yes‚Äîexpense replacement matters even without loans.

### Can I reduce cover as my liabilities reduce?
Some plans allow decreasing cover options; otherwise you can buy additional cover later and plan holistically.

### Should I include future home loan plans?
If you are very likely to take a loan soon, you can add some buffer, but don‚Äôt overbuy purely on speculation.

### Does higher cover increase claim problems?
Claim outcomes depend more on honest disclosure and documentation than cover amount.

### Is employer-provided term cover enough?
Usually no, because it can stop when you change jobs and may be insufficient.

title: "Joint Life Term Insurance in India: For Couples (2026 Guide)"
slug: "/resources/term-insurance/joint-life-term"
description: "Joint life term insurance covers both spouses under one policy. Learn how it works, first-death vs both-death options, premium savings, and whether couples should buy joint or separate term policies."
lastModified: "2026-01-29"
---

## The 30-second answer
Joint life term insurance covers **both spouses under a single policy**. On the first death, the surviving spouse gets the sum assured (and the policy typically ends). It's **10-15% cheaper** than two separate policies, but you lose flexibility. For most couples, **separate policies are better** unless budget is very tight ‚Äî the surviving spouse then has their own independent cover.

**Back to:** [Term Insurance Guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Joint policy:** One premium, covers both
- **Payout:** Usually on first death (surviving spouse receives)
- **Premium savings:** 10-15% vs two separate policies
- **Flexibility trade-off:** Less control than individual policies
- **Best for:** Budget-conscious couples where both have similar cover needs

---

## How joint life term insurance works

### First-death (most common)
- Policy pays out when the first spouse dies
- Surviving spouse receives the entire sum assured
- **Policy terminates** ‚Äî survivor has no cover afterward

### Joint-life last survivor (rare in India)
- Policy pays out when the second spouse dies
- Used mainly for estate planning
- **Not common** for family protection

### Both-lives (some insurers)
- Payout on first death AND reduced cover continues for survivor
- Higher premium than standard joint policy
- Better protection but more expensive

---

## Joint vs separate policies: Comparison

| Factor | Joint Policy | Separate Policies |
|--------|--------------|-------------------|
| **Premium** | Lower (10-15% savings) | Higher total cost |
| **Flexibility** | Less ‚Äî one policy, one term | More ‚Äî different amounts, tenures |
| **After first death** | Policy usually ends | Survivor's policy continues |
| **Divorce** | Complicated to split | Each keeps their own |
| **Nomination** | Each other (fixed) | Can nominate anyone |
| **Cover customization** | Same amount for both | Different amounts possible |

### Recommendation
**Separate policies for most couples** ‚Äî the surviving spouse still needs protection after the first death.

---

## When joint life term makes sense

1. **Tight budget:** Can't afford two separate policies
2. **Dual income, no kids:** Main goal is to protect each other
3. **Home loan protection:** Banks sometimes offer joint loan cover
4. **Equal cover needs:** Both spouses need similar sum assured

### When to avoid joint policies

1. **Different cover needs:** One earns more, needs more cover
2. **Age gap:** Different optimal tenures
3. **Planning for divorce:** (happens more than people admit)
4. **Want flexibility:** Ability to modify policies independently

---

## Premium comparison: Joint vs Separate

### Example: Couple (both 30, non-smokers, ‚Çπ1 crore each, 30-year term)

| Option | Annual Premium | Total Cover |
|--------|----------------|-------------|
| **Joint policy** | ‚Çπ14,000-16,000 | ‚Çπ1 crore (first death) |
| **Two separate policies** | ‚Çπ16,000-19,000 | ‚Çπ2 crore (‚Çπ1 cr each) |
| **Difference** | ~15% savings | But less total protection |

### The hidden cost
With joint policy: After first death, survivor has **zero cover**.
With separate policies: Survivor still has their **‚Çπ1 crore cover**.

**True comparison:** Joint saves ‚Çπ2,000-3,000/year but leaves survivor unprotected.

---

## City-wise examples

### Mumbai
- Couple (30M + 28F), joint ‚Çπ1 crore, 30 years: ‚Çπ14,500-16,500/year
- Same couple, separate policies: ‚Çπ8,500 (M) + ‚Çπ7,500 (F) = ‚Çπ16,000/year
- Savings: ~‚Çπ500-1,500/year

### Delhi
- Couple (35M + 32F), joint ‚Çπ1.5 crore, 25 years: ‚Çπ22,000-25,000/year
- Separate policies: ‚Çπ14,000 (M) + ‚Çπ10,500 (F) = ‚Çπ24,500/year
- Savings: ~‚Çπ500-2,500/year

### Bangalore
- Couple (28M + 28F), joint ‚Çπ75 lakh, 30 years: ‚Çπ10,500-12,000/year
- Separate policies: ‚Çπ6,500 (M) + ‚Çπ5,500 (F) = ‚Çπ12,000/year
- Savings: ~‚Çπ500-1,500/year

---

| Question | If Yes ‚Üí | If No ‚Üí |
|----------|----------|---------|
| Can you afford two policies? | Separate | Consider joint |
| Do you have children? | Separate (more protection) | Either |
| Different income levels? | Separate (customize cover) | Either |
| Same age (¬±3 years)? | Either | Separate (different tenures) |
| Planning long-term together? | Either | Separate (flexibility) |

---

## What happens in different scenarios

### Scenario 1: First spouse dies
- **Joint policy:** Survivor gets ‚Çπ1 crore, policy ends, no further cover
- **Separate policies:** Survivor gets ‚Çπ1 crore from deceased's policy, still has their own ‚Çπ1 crore cover

### Scenario 2: Divorce
- **Joint policy:** Complex ‚Äî need to surrender or convert; may lose money
- **Separate policies:** Each keeps their own policy, update nominee

### Scenario 3: One spouse becomes uninsurable
- **Joint policy:** Policy continues for both
- **Separate policies:** Uninsurable spouse keeps existing policy; other can modify theirs

### Scenario 4: Both die simultaneously (accident)
- **Joint policy:** Typically pays one sum assured to nominated heirs
- **Separate policies:** Both policies pay out (‚Çπ2 crore total)

## How to buy joint life term insurance

### Step 1: Assess needs together
- Calculate combined liabilities
- Discuss income replacement for both scenarios

### Step 2: Compare options
- Get quotes for joint AND separate policies
- Factor in the "survivor unprotected" risk

### Step 3: Apply together
- Both spouses complete proposal forms
- Both undergo medical tests (if required)
- Joint signatures on policy documents

### Step 4: Set up nomination
- Typically each other + contingent nominee (children/parents)
- Update after life events

---

## Common mistakes couples make

1. **Only considering premium savings** ‚Äî The 10-15% savings isn't worth leaving survivor unprotected
2. **Not planning for divorce** ‚Äî Joint policies are messy to split
3. **Buying same cover when needs differ** ‚Äî The higher earner usually needs more
4. **Forgetting about children** ‚Äî Kids need protection regardless of which parent dies first
5. **Not reviewing after life changes** ‚Äî Marriage, kids, income changes need policy review

## FAQs

### What is joint life term insurance?
A single term insurance policy that covers both spouses. On the first death, the surviving spouse receives the sum assured, and the policy typically ends.

### Is joint term insurance cheaper than buying two policies?
Yes, typically 10-15% cheaper. But the surviving spouse has no cover after the first death, which may not be worth the savings.

### What happens to a joint policy if we divorce?
It's complicated. Options include: surrendering the policy (losing value), converting to individual policies (if insurer allows), or one spouse buying out the other's share.

### Can same-sex partners buy joint life term insurance in India?
Currently, most Indian insurers define joint life policies for legally married couples. Same-sex marriages aren't legally recognized in India yet, limiting options.

### Should we buy joint or separate policies?
For most couples, **separate policies are better**. The surviving spouse still needs protection, and you get more flexibility to customize cover amounts and tenures.

### What if one spouse is older? Does age affect joint premiums?
Yes, joint policy premiums are based on the older or higher-risk spouse's age/health. If there's a significant age gap, separate policies may be more cost-effective.

### Can we add riders to joint policies?
Yes, most joint policies allow riders like critical illness and accidental death. Both spouses are typically covered under the same riders.

### What's the maximum cover available in joint life policies?
Usually same as individual policies ‚Äî ‚Çπ5-25 crore depending on income and insurer. Combined cover is based on combined income.

### Do both spouses need medical tests?
Yes, both undergo the insurer's underwriting process including medical tests if sum assured exceeds limits.

### What if one spouse has health issues?
The policy premium may be loaded based on the higher-risk spouse, or that spouse may be declined and you'll need separate policies.

### Can unmarried couples buy joint life term insurance?
Generally no ‚Äî Indian insurers require a marriage certificate for joint life policies. Live-in partners typically cannot buy joint term cover.

### How do we update nominees in a joint policy?
Both spouses sign the nomination change form. Typically, the primary nominee is each other, with children or parents as contingent nominees.

## The 30-second answer
A **nominee** is the person you name in your policy to receive claim money. A **legal heir** is determined by succession law or a will. In India, nomination usually helps the insurer **pay quickly**, but it may not always override succession rights. The practical goal is to keep nomination updated, align it with your will/family plan, and keep documents clean so your family doesn‚Äôt get stuck.

**Back to:** [Term Insurance guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Goal:** make sure your family gets a clean payout if you‚Äôre not around.
- **Avoid:** hiding medical/tobacco history, choosing too-short tenure, and messy nomination.
- **Prefer:** a simple plan, right cover + tenure, and honest disclosures (even for occasional tobacco).
- **Claims-first:** keep policy PDF, premium receipts, nominee KYC, and insurer contact details handy.

---

| Action | Why |
|---|---|
| Add nominee(s) correctly (name, DOB, relation) | Avoid delays |
| Update nomination after marriage/child | Most common miss |
| Keep a simple will (if needed) | Align legal intent |
| Keep policy documents accessible to family | Faster claim |
| Inform nominee where documents are stored | Less stress |

---

## Nominee vs legal heir: simple explanation
### Nominee
- Appointed in the policy
- Helps insurer know **who to pay**
- May act as a receiver/trustee in certain legal interpretations

### Legal heir
- Determined by succession law (or a will)
- Final rightful ownership can depend on personal law and estate planning

**Practical takeaway:** nomination is necessary, but estate clarity (and family communication) matters too.

---

- Married with kids: spouse is often nominee; consider appointee/guardian if nominee is minor

## The 30-second answer
Yes, NRIs can buy term insurance in India‚Äîand often should, especially if they have **Indian dependents, home loans, or plan to return**. Most insurers accept NRIs from low/medium-risk countries (USA, UK, UAE, Singapore, Canada, Australia). Premium is similar to resident Indians, though some insurers add 10-15% loading. Key requirements: valid Indian address for correspondence, NRE/NRO account for premium payment, and documents proving NRI status.

**Back to:** [Term Insurance guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Goal:** make sure your family gets a clean payout if you're not around.
- **Avoid:** hiding medical/tobacco history, choosing too-short tenure, and messy nomination.
- **Prefer:** a simple plan, right cover + tenure, and honest disclosures (even for occasional tobacco).
- **Claims-first:** keep policy PDF, premium receipts, nominee KYC, and insurer contact details handy.

---

## Why NRIs Should Consider Indian Term Insurance

| Reason | Explanation |
|---|---|
| **Lower premiums** | Indian term insurance is 50-70% cheaper than US/UK policies |
| **Family in India** | If dependents are in India, rupee payout makes sense |
| **Home loan** | If you have Indian property loan, Indian cover protects it |
| **Return plans** | If planning to return, Indian policy offers continuity |
| **Tax benefits** | 80C benefit available if you file taxes in India |

### Premium comparison (‚Çπ1 Cr cover, age 35, non-smoker)
| Country | Annual Premium (Equivalent) |
|---|---|
| India | ‚Çπ13,500 |
| USA | ‚Çπ35,000-45,000 |
| UK | ‚Çπ28,000-38,000 |
| UAE | ‚Çπ25,000-32,000 |

---

## NRI Eligibility by Country

| Country Category | Examples | Insurability |
|---|---|---|
| **Category A (Low risk)** | USA, UK, Canada, Australia, Singapore, UAE, Germany | ‚úÖ Accepted by most insurers |
| **Category B (Medium risk)** | Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Kuwait, Oman, Hong Kong, Japan | ‚úÖ Accepted with possible loading |
| **Category C (High risk)** | Some African countries, conflict zones | ‚ö†Ô∏è Limited insurers, higher loading |
| **Not accepted** | War zones, sanctioned countries | ‚ùå Declined |

**Note:** Categories vary by insurer. Always check with specific company.

---

## Documents Required for NRIs

### Mandatory documents
| Document | Purpose |
|---|---|
| Valid passport (Indian/foreign) | Identity proof |
| Valid visa/work permit/PR card | Proof of NRI status |
| Overseas address proof | Utility bill, bank statement |
| Indian address proof | For correspondence (family address OK) |
| PAN card | KYC requirement |
| Passport-size photos | 2-4 copies |

### Financial documents
| Document | Purpose |
|---|---|
| NRE/NRO bank statement | Premium payment source |
| Salary certificate/employment letter | Income proof for high cover |
| Last 2 years' tax returns (overseas) | For cover > ‚Çπ2 Cr |

### Medical documents (if applicable)
| Document | When needed |
|---|---|
| Medical test reports | Cover > ‚Çπ1 Cr or age > 40 |
| Existing policy details | If you have other life cover |
| Medical history declaration | Always required |

---

## How to Buy: Step-by-Step Process

### Step 1: Choose insurer (check NRI acceptance)
Not all insurers accept all NRI categories. Verify your country is accepted.

| Insurer | NRI-Friendly? | Online Purchase? |
|---|---|---|
| HDFC Life | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚úÖ Yes |
| ICICI Prudential | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚úÖ Yes |
| Max Life | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚ö†Ô∏è Limited |
| Tata AIA | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚úÖ Yes |
| LIC | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚ùå Offline only |

### Step 2: Complete application
- Fill proposal form (online or physical)
- Declare NRI status, country of residence
- Provide overseas and Indian addresses
- Disclose complete health history

### Step 3: Submit documents
- Upload/courier documents
- Video KYC available with some insurers
- Processing takes 5-15 business days

### Step 4: Medical examination (if required)
- Can be done in India during visit
- Or at approved centers abroad (limited cities)
- Some insurers have tie-ups in USA, UK, UAE, Singapore

### Step 5: Premium payment
- First premium via NRE/NRO account
- International cards accepted by some insurers
- Set up auto-debit for renewals

### Step 6: Policy issuance
- E-policy delivered via email
- Physical copy sent to Indian address
- Verify all details, nominee, sum assured

---

## Premium Payment Options for NRIs

| Payment Method | Accepted? | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| NRE account | ‚úÖ Yes | Preferred method |
| NRO account | ‚úÖ Yes | Rupee account |
| International credit card | ‚ö†Ô∏è Some insurers | Check with insurer |
| Wire transfer | ‚ö†Ô∏è Limited | For first premium |
| Indian family member's account | ‚ùå No | Compliance issues |

**Auto-renewal tip:** Set up standing instruction from NRE/NRO account to avoid lapse.

---

## Claim Process for NRI Policies

If the worst happens, your nominee (usually in India) will file the claim.

### Documents needed for death claim
| Document | Notes |
|---|---|
| Death certificate | Original or attested copy |
| Policy document | Original |
| Claimant's ID proof | Nominee's documents |
| Claimant's bank details | For payout |
| FIR (if accidental death) | If applicable |
| Medical records | If death due to illness |
| Embassy attestation | If death occurred abroad |

### Claim payout timeline
- Insurers must settle within **30 days** of document submission (IRDAI mandate)
- Payout to nominee's Indian bank account
- No TDS on death benefit (tax-free under 10(10D))

3. Apostille may be required (Hague Convention countries)
4. Submit translated copy if not in English

### Country of residence change
- Inform insurer if you move to a different country
- Some countries may require policy review
- Moving to high-risk country may need additional premium

- Policy continues without change

## The 30-second answer
Return of Premium (ROP) term plans return premiums at maturity if you survive. They feel reassuring, but premiums are much higher; effectively you‚Äôre paying extra for a forced, low-flexibility ‚Äúrefund‚Äù. Many people are better off buying a **plain term plan** and investing the difference.

- **Claims-first:** keep policy PDF, premium receipts, nominee KYC, and insurer contact details handy.

---

## Quick pros/cons table
| ROP term plans | What it means |
|---|---|
| Pro: Refund if you survive | Psychological comfort |
| Con: Higher premium | Lower cost-efficiency for protection |
| Con: Low flexibility | Money is locked till maturity |
| Con: Opportunity cost | Investing the difference may do better |

---

## A practical way to decide
1) First ensure you can afford the **right cover amount**
2) If ROP premium forces you to buy lower cover, prefer plain term

## The 30-second answer
Riders can add useful protection, but only if you understand **when they pay** and **what they exclude**. For many people, the most sensible add-ons are **accidental disability/waiver of premium** (depending on insurer terms). Be cautious with **critical illness riders**‚Äîthey can have strict definitions and survival periods.

**Back to:** [Term Insurance guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Goal:** make sure your family gets a clean payout if you‚Äôre not around.
- **Avoid:** hiding medical/tobacco history, choosing too-short tenure, and messy nomination.
- **Prefer:** a simple plan, right cover + tenure, and honest disclosures (even for occasional tobacco).
- **Claims-first:** keep policy PDF, premium receipts, nominee KYC, and insurer contact details handy.

---

## Quick rider decision table
| Rider | When it helps | Key watch-outs |
|---|---|---|
| Accidental Death Benefit (ADB) | Extra payout for accidental death | Many deaths are non-accidental; duplicates base benefit logic |
| Accidental Total & Permanent Disability | Income protection if disability stops work | Definition of disability and proof requirements |
| Waiver of Premium | Keeps policy active if disability/CI occurs | Trigger conditions vary |
| Critical Illness (CI) | Lump sum on specified diagnosis | Strict definitions, waiting/survival periods, exclusions |
| Hospital cash | Small daily cash benefit | Not a substitute for health insurance |

---

## A simple framework to decide riders
1) **Start with the core term cover** (don‚Äôt under-buy cover to afford riders)
2) Buy riders only for risks that can hurt you **while alive** (disability/illness)
3) Read the rider wording: definitions, exclusions, waiting/survival periods

Related: [How much term cover do I need?](/resources/term-insurance/how-much-cover)

---

## Rider deep-dive (practical)
### 1) Accidental disability / waiver of premium
These can be valuable because disability can stop income but you‚Äôre still alive with expenses.

### 2) Critical illness rider
Common issues:
- ‚ÄúEarly stage‚Äù may not qualify
- Survival period (e.g., 30 days) can apply
- The illness list and definitions matter more than the marketing name

For some families, a separate health cover strategy is better.

description: "A practical guide to term insurance riders in India: accidental death, accidental disability, critical illness, waiver of premium‚Äîwhat they cover, claim traps, and how to decide."
---

## The 30-second answer
Riders can add useful protection, but only if you understand **when they pay** and **what they exclude**. For many people, the most sensible add-ons are **accidental disability/waiver of premium** (depending on insurer terms). Be cautious with **critical illness riders**‚Äîthey can have strict definitions and survival periods.


**Back to:** [Term Insurance guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)


## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Goal:** make sure your family gets a clean payout if you‚Äôre not around.
- **Avoid:** hiding medical/tobacco history, choosing too-short tenure, and messy nomination.
- **Prefer:** a simple plan, right cover + tenure, and honest disclosures (even for occasional tobacco).
- **Claims-first:** keep policy PDF, premium receipts, nominee KYC, and insurer contact details handy.

---

## Quick rider decision table
| Rider | When it helps | Key watch-outs |
|---|---|---|
| Accidental Death Benefit (ADB) | Extra payout for accidental death | Many deaths are non-accidental; duplicates base benefit logic |
| Accidental Total & Permanent Disability | Income protection if disability stops work | Definition of disability and proof requirements |
| Waiver of Premium | Keeps policy active if disability/CI occurs | Trigger conditions vary |
| Critical Illness (CI) | Lump sum on specified diagnosis | Strict definitions, waiting/survival periods, exclusions |
| Hospital cash | Small daily cash benefit | Not a substitute for health insurance |

---

## A simple framework to decide riders
1) **Start with the core term cover** (don‚Äôt under-buy cover to afford riders)
2) Buy riders only for risks that can hurt you **while alive** (disability/illness)
3) Read the rider wording: definitions, exclusions, waiting/survival periods

Related: [How much term cover do I need?](/resources/term-insurance/how-much-cover)

---

## Rider deep-dive (practical)
### 1) Accidental disability / waiver of premium
These can be valuable because disability can stop income but you‚Äôre still alive with expenses.

### 2) Critical illness rider
Common issues:
- ‚ÄúEarly stage‚Äù may not qualify
- Survival period (e.g., 30 days) can apply
- The illness list and definitions matter more than the marketing name

For some families, a separate health cover strategy is better.

---

## Avoid these common mistakes
- Buying many riders without understanding claim triggers
- Assuming CI rider = health insurance (it isn‚Äôt)
- Choosing the cheapest plan where riders have restrictive wording

---

**Team**
- **Harsh Soni (Founder & CEO):** 16+ years in fintech, banking & investment banking.
- **Kshitij Jain (Co-Founder):** Ex-BCG consultant; IIM Ahmedabad & IIT Delhi alumnus.


## FAQs
### Are riders mandatory?
No. They are optional add-ons.

### Which is the best rider to add?
If you add one, many people start with disability/waiver of premium‚Äîdepending on wording and cost.

### Do riders increase claim rejection risk?
They add more conditions and paperwork. Core term claims are simpler than rider claims.

### Is critical illness rider better than a separate CI plan?
Depends on pricing and definitions. Many people prefer a separate health insurance strategy rather than relying on CI riders.

### Does accidental death rider make sense?
Sometimes, but remember many real-world deaths are due to illness, not accidents.

### Can I add riders later?
Sometimes yes, but you may need medicals and it can be costlier.

### Are riders tax-deductible?
Tax treatment varies by product type and laws; check current rules or consult a tax professional.

### Do riders pay in addition to base term cover?
Usually yes if the trigger is met, but confirm the rider structure.

slug: "/resources/term-insurance/tenure"
description: "How to choose the right term insurance policy tenure in India (till 55/60/65/70): a needs-based method based on dependents, loans, and retirement plan‚Äîplus a quick decision table."
---

## The 30-second answer
Choose term insurance tenure until the age your family would be **financially safe without your income**‚Äîusually when major loans are cleared and dependents are independent. For many earners, that‚Äôs **60‚Äì65**; for people with late kids/large liabilities, it can be longer.

**Back to:** [Term Insurance guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Goal:** make sure your family gets a clean payout if you‚Äôre not around.
- **Avoid:** hiding medical/tobacco history, choosing too-short tenure, and messy nomination.
- **Prefer:** a simple plan, right cover + tenure, and honest disclosures (even for occasional tobacco).
- **Claims-first:** keep policy PDF, premium receipts, nominee KYC, and insurer contact details handy.

---

## Quick decision table
| Your situation | Tenure that usually makes sense |
|---|---|
| No dependents, no major loans | Shorter tenure or postpone (case-by-case) |
| Home loan till age 55‚Äì60 | At least until loan end (add buffer) |
| Kids <10 years | Often until 60‚Äì65 (or till kids are independent) |
| Late marriage/late kids | Consider 65‚Äì70 |
| Strong retirement corpus + low liabilities early | Possibly 55‚Äì60 |

---

## A simple 3-step method to pick tenure
### 1) Map your ‚Äúdependency end date‚Äù
When will dependents likely not need your income?
- Kids finishing education
- Spouse having stable income/assets
- Parents‚Äô dependency reducing (or separate planning)

### 2) Map your ‚Äúliability end date‚Äù
- Home loan completion
- Other loans
- Any guarantees

### 3) Pick the later of the two (and add a small buffer)
A buffer helps because real life is messy (job switches, medical issues, delayed goals).

---

## Why ‚Äúlonger tenure is always better‚Äù is not always true
Long tenures can be useful, but:
- Premiums rise with age
- You may not need cover after you‚Äôve built assets
- Policy value is about protecting dependents during working years

The right answer is ‚Äúcover the risky years‚Äù, not ‚Äúcover forever.‚Äù

---

## Common mistakes
- Choosing tenure based only on lowest premium
- Ending coverage before loan tenure ends
- Ignoring late-life responsibilities (late kids, dependent parents)

---

### Should I take term insurance till 60 or 65?
If your dependents and liabilities last into your early 60s, 65 can be safer. If you‚Äôll be financially independent by 60, 60 may be enough.

Often less needed if you have a strong retirement corpus and no dependents relying on your income.

The policy ends and no benefit is payable (unless it‚Äôs a return-of-premium variant).

Usually you can buy a new plan later, but it will be costlier and may require medicals.

It increases the time window, but claim success depends on disclosure and documentation.

Not always ‚Äúmuch higher‚Äù, but there is usually an increase.

That‚Äôs a good anchor point, yes.

At minimum, yes‚Äîideally add a small buffer beyond loan end.

|---|---|

| Honest disclosure | Matches medical records |
| Willingness for medicals | Faster underwriting decisions |

- Approve at standard rates (sometimes)
- Approve with premium loading
- Approve with exclusions (less common in pure term; varies)
- Postpone/decline in higher-risk cases

- Keep recent reports ready

slug: "/resources/term-insurance/women-guide"
description: "Women pay 20-30% lower term insurance premiums than men. Learn why, how much cover you need, and what working and non-working women should consider when buying term insurance in India."

## The 30-second answer
Women get **20-30% lower premiums** on term insurance compared to men of the same age because of longer life expectancy. Whether you're working or a homemaker, term insurance protects your family's financial future. A working woman should cover **income replacement + liabilities**; a homemaker should consider the **replacement cost of household contributions** (often ‚Çπ25-50 lakh).

**Back to:** [Term Insurance Guide](/resources/term-insurance/guide)

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Working women:** Cover 10-15x annual income + liabilities
- **Homemakers:** Consider ‚Çπ25-50 lakh to cover household contribution value
- **Premium advantage:** 20-30% lower than men
- **Key riders:** Critical illness, waiver of premium
- **Buy early:** Premiums locked at purchase age

---

## Why women pay lower premiums

| Factor | Impact |
|--------|--------|
| **Longer life expectancy** | Women live ~3-5 years longer on average |
| **Lower mortality risk** | Fewer claims = lower premiums |
| **Lifestyle factors** | Lower rates of smoking, alcohol |
| **Occupation risk** | Often lower-risk occupations |

### Premium comparison: Women vs Men (‚Çπ1 Crore cover, 30 years)

| Age | Women (Annual) | Men (Annual) | Savings |
|-----|----------------|--------------|---------|
| 25 | ‚Çπ6,500-7,500 | ‚Çπ8,000-9,500 | ~20% |
| 30 | ‚Çπ7,500-9,000 | ‚Çπ9,500-11,500 | ~22% |
| 35 | ‚Çπ10,000-12,000 | ‚Çπ13,000-16,000 | ~25% |
| 40 | ‚Çπ15,000-18,000 | ‚Çπ20,000-25,000 | ~28% |

*Premiums are indicative for non-smokers; actual rates vary by insurer.*

---

## How much cover do working women need?

### The income replacement method

| Component | Calculation |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Annual income** | Your current salary |
| **Multiplier** | 10-15x (depending on dependents) |
| **Add liabilities** | Home loan, car loan, education loans |
| **Subtract assets** | Existing savings, investments, other insurance |

**Example:** 
- Annual income: ‚Çπ12 lakh
- Multiplier: 12x = ‚Çπ1.44 crore
- Home loan outstanding: ‚Çπ40 lakh
- **Recommended cover: ‚Çπ1.75-2 crore**

Related: [How much term cover do I need?](/resources/term-insurance/how-much-cover)

---

## Term insurance for homemakers

### Why homemakers need term insurance

A homemaker's contributions have real economic value:
- Childcare (‚Çπ15,000-30,000/month if hired)
- Household management
- Elderly care
- Educational support for children

### Recommended cover for homemakers

| City Tier | Replacement Cost | Suggested Cover |
|-----------|------------------|-----------------|
| Metro (Mumbai/Delhi/Bangalore) | ‚Çπ4-6 lakh/year | ‚Çπ40-60 lakh |
| Tier 1 cities | ‚Çπ3-4 lakh/year | ‚Çπ30-40 lakh |
| Tier 2/3 cities | ‚Çπ2-3 lakh/year | ‚Çπ20-30 lakh |

**Note:** Many insurers offer term insurance for homemakers with reduced documentation requirements.

---

## Special considerations for women

### 1. Maternity and term insurance
- **No waiting period:** Term insurance covers death from any cause from day 1 (after initial 12-month suicide clause)
- **Pregnancy:** Disclose if pregnant at application; most insurers accept
- **No maternity exclusion:** Unlike health insurance, term has no maternity-related exclusions

### 2. Critical illness rider
Women-specific conditions to ensure coverage for:
- Breast cancer
- Ovarian cancer  
- Cervical cancer

**Tip:** Add critical illness rider (‚Çπ25-50 lakh) for living benefit protection.

### 3. Single mothers
- **Higher cover recommended:** You're the sole provider
- **Consider:** Income replacement for 15-20 years until children are independent
- **Nomination:** Keep updated; consider trust if children are minors

## Common mistakes women make

1. **Assuming spouse's insurance is enough** ‚Äî Your income/contribution needs separate protection
2. **Buying low cover** ‚Äî Underinsurance defeats the purpose
3. **Not disclosing health conditions** ‚Äî PCOS, thyroid issues must be declared

## FAQs

### Why is term insurance cheaper for women?
Women have longer life expectancy and lower mortality risk, resulting in fewer claims and lower premiums.

### Can a homemaker buy term insurance without income proof?
Yes, many insurers offer term insurance to homemakers based on spouse's income. Cover is typically capped at 50% of spouse's cover or ‚Çπ50 lakh.

### Is term insurance necessary if I'm not working?
Yes. Your household contributions have real economic value. If something happens to you, your family would need to hire help or one spouse may need to reduce work hours.

### What's the ideal age to buy term insurance?
As early as possible. Premiums are locked at purchase age, and you're more likely to qualify without medical loading when young and healthy.

### Should I buy joint term insurance with my spouse?
Joint policies can be cheaper, but separate policies give more flexibility. If one spouse dies, the survivor still has their own cover.

### Do I need to declare PCOS or thyroid issues?
Yes, disclose all pre-existing conditions. Non-disclosure can lead to claim rejection.

### Can I increase cover after having children?
Some policies offer "life stage" benefits allowing cover increase without fresh underwriting after marriage or childbirth.

### What happens to my term policy if I get divorced?
The policy continues unchanged. Update your nominee if your ex-spouse was nominated.

### Is critical illness rider worth it for women?
Yes, especially for women-specific cancers. It provides a lump sum on diagnosis, helping with treatment costs and income loss.

### Can NRI women buy term insurance in India?
Yes, if you have Indian residency proof or are an Indian citizen. Some insurers have specific NRI-friendly policies.

### What if I start smoking after buying the policy?
You don't need to inform the insurer, but it may affect claim investigation if death is tobacco-related.

### How do I compare term plans as a woman?
Focus on: claim settlement ratio, premium for your age, rider options, and insurer's track record with women policyholders.

title: "Why Health Insurance: Medical Inflation, Hospital Costs & Financial Reality"
slug: "/resources/why-health-insurance"
description: "Why health insurance matters in India: medical inflation is 14% annually, hospital bills exceed savings, and corporate cover is not enough. See real hospital cost examples and learn why a personal plan protects your family."
---

## The 30-second answer
Medical inflation in India runs at **14% annually**‚Äîroughly double general inflation. A single major hospitalization can cost ‚Çπ5‚Äì15L depending on your city. Savings alone can't protect you from financial ruin; corporate insurance comes with gaps and can disappear when you change jobs. A solid personal health insurance plan **costs far less than even one major hospital bill** and keeps your savings intact for other goals.

## Quick checklist (above-the-fold)
- **Goal:** protect your family from one large medical bill destroying your finances, not chase the cheapest premium.
- **Reality check:** Medical costs in India rise 14% every year; your savings don't.
- **Corporate insurance:** helpful but not fully in your control; gaps on parents, portability, and continuity.
- **Smart move:** build your own personal base policy + super top-up, treat corporate cover as bonus.
- **First step:** use NYVO's health insurance calculator to size your cover for your city and family.

---

## Why health insurance matters: The numbers

### Medical inflation in India is accelerating
- **General inflation (India):** 5‚Äì6% annually
- **Medical inflation (India):** 14% annually (source: RBI data, hospital networks)
- **What this means:** Hospital bills double roughly every 5 years

### Real hospital bill examples (2025‚Äì2026)
These are actual claims data from Indian networks:

| Procedure | Mumbai | Delhi | Bangalore | Hyderabad |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Bypass surgery** | ‚Çπ5‚Äì7L | ‚Çπ4‚Äì6L | ‚Çπ4.5‚Äì6.5L | ‚Çπ4‚Äì5.5L |
| **Knee replacement** | ‚Çπ3‚Äì4.5L | ‚Çπ2.5‚Äì4L | ‚Çπ3‚Äì4L | ‚Çπ2.5‚Äì3.5L |
| **Cancer chemotherapy (6 cycles)** | ‚Çπ8‚Äì12L | ‚Çπ7‚Äì10L | ‚Çπ7‚Äì9L | ‚Çπ6‚Äì8.5L |
| **ICU hospitalization (per day)** | ‚Çπ15‚Äì25K | ‚Çπ12‚Äì20K | ‚Çπ10‚Äì18K | ‚Çπ8‚Äì15K |
| **Organ transplant** | ‚Çπ15‚Äì25L | ‚Çπ12‚Äì20L | ‚Çπ12‚Äì18L | ‚Çπ10‚Äì15L |

**Key insight:** A 10-day ICU stay alone can cost ‚Çπ1.5‚Äì2.5L in metros. Add surgery costs and you're looking at ‚Çπ5L+ for a single event.

---

## Myth vs Reality: Can savings alone protect you?

### Myth: "I have ‚Çπ10L in savings; I don't need health insurance"
**Reality:**
- If you spend ‚Çπ10L on a single hospital bill, your savings evaporate.
- Medical costs rise 14% annually‚Äînext year your ‚Çπ10L covers less.
- Unexpected hospitalization happens exactly when you *can't* afford to use savings (emergency leave from work, stress, family impact).
- Savings should cover 3‚Äì6 months of living expenses, not hospital bills.

### Better approach: Insurance + Savings
1. Buy **personal health insurance** (base + super top-up)
2. Keep your ‚Çπ10L savings for **actual emergencies and life goals** (education, retirement)
3. If you get hospitalized, insurance pays; savings stay intact

---

## Why corporate insurance alone isn't enough

### Corporate insurance gaps checklist
| Gap | Why it matters | Real example |
|---|---|---|
| **Not portable** | When you change jobs, coverage ends | Switched company ‚Üí lost cover for 6 months ‚Üí had to delay needed treatment |
| **No continuity** | Employer changes insurer or cuts benefits | Company switched TPA ‚Üí network hospitals changed ‚Üí lost preferred doctor |
| **Parents usually excluded** | Or covered with heavy co-pay and limits | Parent hospitalized ‚Üí only 40% of bill covered ‚Üí out-of-pocket ‚Çπ2L |
| **Sub-limits and co-pay** | Room rent limits, co-pay mean you still pay a lot | ‚Çπ5L bill ‚Üí ‚Çπ1L room rent not covered ‚Üí ‚Çπ2.5L co-pay (50%) ‚Üí out-of-pocket ‚Çπ3.5L |
| **Claim support varies** | Employer's TPA may not assist during complex claims | Complex reimbursement claim ‚Üí TPA didn't help ‚Üí had to chase bills ourselves |
| **Coverage can reduce** | If company faces financial pressure, benefits shrink | Company downsizing ‚Üí health cover reduced to ‚Çπ3L (from ‚Çπ5L) |
| **Dependent coverage limits** | Kids and spouse sometimes have lower limits | Wife hospitalized ‚Üí corporate cover only ‚Çπ2L ‚Üí needed ‚Çπ4.5L ‚Üí out-of-pocket ‚Çπ2.5L |

### Real scenario
**Rajesh (age 42, employed at tech firm, ‚Çπ1.2Cr household income):**
- Corporate health cover: ‚Çπ5L family floater
- No personal insurance
- Undergoes bypass surgery: ‚Çπ6.5L bill
- Corporate cover pays: ‚Çπ5L
- Out-of-pocket: ‚Çπ1.5L
- Later changes jobs ‚Üí new employer's cover has heavy co-pay and lower network
- Lesson: Corporate insurance = helpful, but not enough

---

## Why a personal health insurance plan makes sense

### The true cost of NOT having insurance
- **One major hospitalization:** ‚Çπ5‚Äì15L (happens to ~2 in 100 people per year in metros)
- **Average premium for personal base + super top-up:** ‚Çπ300‚Äì800/month (~‚Çπ4‚Äì10K/year)
- **ROI:** Costs ‚Çπ50K to protect against ‚Çπ500K+ risk

### What a personal plan does
1. **Protects your savings:** Bills are paid by insurance, not your bank account
2. **Covers your family continuity:** Works when you change jobs
3. **Covers parents:** Separate personal plans for parents are often cheaper than corporate add-ons
4. **Works with corporate as bonus:** Corporate cover + personal = better protection
5. **Clear claim process:** You know the terms before you need it

### Building the right structure: Base + Super Top-up
**Example: Family of 3 (2 kids, both earning parents, parents nearby)**

1. **Base policy:** ‚Çπ10L per person, ‚Çπ15L family floater (whichever is higher)
   - Covers ‚Çπ0 to ‚Çπ10L per hospitalization
   - Premium: ~‚Çπ300/month for family

2. **Super top-up:** ‚Çπ10L deductible, ‚Çπ50L cover
   - Kicks in after base policy is exhausted
   - Protects against larger bills
   - Premium: ~‚Çπ150/month for family

**Total:** ‚Çπ450/month, ‚Çπ5.4K/year ‚Üí protects against ‚Çπ1‚Äì2L bills easily

---

## Who should buy health insurance (and how much)

### You should definitely buy insurance if:
- You have family dependents (spouse, kids, parents)
- You live in a metro or tier-1 city (costs are highest)
- You have any pre-existing conditions (delays are worse without insurance)
- You are your family's main earner
- Your savings are less than ‚Çπ25L

### Cover sizing rules of thumb
| Situation | Suggested cover |
|---|---|
| Young couple, no dependents, no savings | ‚Çπ10L personal + ‚Çπ15L super top-up |
| Salaried family with 2 kids | ‚Çπ15L base (family or individual) + ‚Çπ25L super top-up |
| Self-employed with higher risk | ‚Çπ20L base + ‚Çπ50L super top-up |
| Parents as dependents too | ‚Çπ20L base per person + ‚Çπ50L super top-up for family |
| Pre-existing conditions | Start with clear terms on waiting periods; don't cheap out on premium |

---

## Common mistakes that cost people money

### Mistake 1: Buying a cheap policy with room rent limits
- Premium saved: ‚Çπ1,000/year
- Room rent not covered in ‚Çπ5L bill: ‚Çπ1L
- **Net loss: ‚Çπ99,000**

### Mistake 2: Relying only on corporate insurance
- Coverage ends when job changes
- Family loses cover for months ‚Üí delayed treatment
- Emergency hospitalization while uninsured ‚Üí full out-of-pocket

### Mistake 3: Not buying insurance until you're older
- Premiums at 40 cost 3‚Äì5x more than premiums at 30
- Waiting periods for pre-existing conditions start fresh with each policy
- A 35-year-old paying ‚Çπ500/month today avoids ‚Çπ1,500/month at 45

### Mistake 4: Not disclosing health conditions to save on premium
- Claim gets rejected due to non-disclosure
- You lose the full premium *and* have to pay the hospital bill

### Mistake 5: Buying too much coverage of one type (skipping super top-up structure)
- Premium is higher per rupee of cover
- Claims have more complex sub-limits
- Base + super top-up is usually more efficient

---

## How to get the right health insurance plan

### Step 1: Use a calculator to size your cover
- Consider your city (treatment costs vary 30‚Äì50% between metros and tier-2 cities)
- Account for your age, family size, and existing savings
- Factor in medical inflation (your cover should handle 5‚Äì10 years of inflation)

**NYVO Health Insurance Calculator:** https://www.nyvo.in/calculator

### Step 2: Understand base + super top-up structure
- Read: [Base vs Super Top-up](/resources/health-insurance/base-vs-super-top-up)
- Compare using the same deductible across options

### Step 3: Check the 7 features that matter
- Room rent limits (avoid or understand fully)
- Co-pay percentage
- Waiting periods (especially for PED)
- Pre-existing disease definitions
- Network hospitals in your city
- Restoration benefits
- No Claim Bonus (nice-to-have, not core)

### Step 4: Check corporate insurance gaps
- Read: [Corporate insurance isn't enough](/resources/health-insurance/corporate-insurance-not-enough)
- Plan personal cover *in addition to*, not *instead of*, corporate

### Step 5: Get claims-ready before you need it
- Read: [Health insurance claims guide](/resources/claims/health-insurance-claims-guide)
- Keep documents, policy PDFs, TPA contact info handy
- Know the cashless approval process

---

## Medical inflation data: Why 14% matters

### How medical costs compound
| Year | Assumed cost (starting ‚Çπ5L) | Multiplied by 14% inflation |
|---|---|---|
| 2025 | ‚Çπ5L | baseline |
| 2030 | ‚Çπ10.04L | 2x |
| 2035 | ‚Çπ20.07L | 4x |
| 2040 | ‚Çπ40.14L | 8x |

**Key insight:** A bypass surgery that costs ‚Çπ5L today could cost ‚Çπ10L in 5 years and ‚Çπ20L in 10 years. Buying insurance *now* at today's premium locks in that lower cost.

### Why medical inflation is higher than general inflation
- Diagnostic technology costs rise faster than general prices
- Specialist doctor fees increase with demand
- Hospital infrastructure (ICU equipment, COVID protocols) is expensive
- Insurance claims drive up hospital pricing

---

## The NYVO approach to health insurance

### What we do differently
1. **Calculator-first:** We help you size cover based on your city, family, and age‚Äînot by guessing
2. **Claims-first:** We recommend plans based on how they *actually* pay claims, not marketing
3. **Conflict-free:** We don't push products; we guide you through options
4. **End-to-end support:** We help with setup, disclosures, and claims handling

### Why education matters
Most people buy insurance based on premium alone. We believe the smarter move is understanding:
- Why cover sizing matters more than premium
- How medical inflation affects your future costs
- Why base + super top-up usually beats one large policy
- What claims-first really means

---

## Related articles
- [Health Insurance Guide (complete)](/resources/health-insurance/guide)
- [How much health insurance cover do I need?](/resources/health-insurance/how-much-cover)
- [Base vs Super Top-up](/resources/health-insurance/base-vs-super-top-up)
- [Corporate insurance isn't enough](/resources/health-insurance/corporate-insurance-not-enough)
- [Health insurance claims guide](/resources/claims/health-insurance-claims-guide)
- [Medical inflation in India (detailed data)](/resources/general/medical-inflation-india)

---

## Next steps
1. **Use the calculator:** Size your cover ‚Üí https://www.nyvo.in/calculator
2. **Book a call:** Talk through your family's situation with a NYVO advisor (free, no spam) ‚Üí https://www.nyvo.in/book-a-call
3. **Read deeper:** Explore base + super top-up structure, waiting periods, and claims checklists

---

## Editorial policy + author credentials
NYVO Resources are written to be **practical and claims-first** for Indian families.

**Our editorial principles**
- **Conflict-free:** we focus on clarity and suitability, not product hype.
- **No spam:** we don't sell your data; we keep advice simple and actionable.
- **Claims-first:** policy features are evaluated by how they behave during claims.
- **Education-first:** this content is informational and must be validated against policy wordings.

**Team**
- **Harsh Soni (Founder & CEO):** 16+ years in fintech, banking & investment banking.
- **Kshitij Jain (Co-Founder):** Ex-BCG consultant; IIM Ahmedabad & IIT Delhi alumnus.

## FAQs

### Why is medical inflation 14% when general inflation is only 5‚Äì6%?
Medical inflation is driven by diagnostic technology costs, specialist fees, hospital infrastructure, and insurance claims driving up prices‚Äîfactors that grow faster than general goods and services.

### If I have ‚Çπ15L in savings, do I need health insurance?
Often yes. A single major hospitalization (bypass, cancer, organ transplant) can consume all your savings and leave you unable to handle other emergencies. Insurance keeps savings intact for actual life goals.

### Is it better to buy one large policy (‚Çπ50L) or base + super top-up?
Usually base + super top-up is more cost-efficient and has clearer claim structures, but it depends on insurer terms. We can help you compare.

### Can I rely on corporate insurance instead of buying personal insurance?
Corporate is helpful but comes with gaps. When you change jobs, coverage ends. Corporate limits may not match your actual needs. A personal plan (even just a base policy) provides continuity.

### At what age should I buy health insurance?
As soon as you have dependents or are your family's main earner. Premiums are significantly lower when bought young (30s vs 40s can be 3‚Äì5x higher).

### What's the cheapest health insurance I can buy?
The cheapest is not the smartest. A cheap policy with room rent limits, co-pay, and low network may cost ‚Çπ200/month but leave you with ‚Çπ2‚Äì3L out-of-pocket during a claim. A fair-priced policy (‚Çπ400‚Äì600/month) with clear terms usually saves you money overall.

### Do I need to buy separate insurance for parents?
Often yes. Parents have age-related premiums (higher), higher claim probability, and pre-existing conditions. A separate personal plan for each parent is usually cheaper than adding them to your family floater.

### How do I know if I'm paying a fair price for health insurance?
Compare 3‚Äì4 plans with the *same deductible*, *same network*, and *same waiting periods*. Premium alone is meaningless; focus on what the policy actually covers during a claim.

### Should I buy health insurance before or after marriage?
Before, if possible. Marital status doesn't affect premium significantly, but health conditions discovered during marriage (if undisclosed) can cause claim denials. Buy early, disclose fully.

### What happens if I can't afford the premium I need for my cover?
Start with a base policy (even ‚Çπ5L) and add a super top-up later. An incomplete structure is better than no structure. Alternatively, adjust your family's coverage (start with spouse + self, add kids later).

---

*Disclaimer: This is educational content, not personalized insurance advice. Medical costs, inflation rates, and policy terms vary by insurer and location. Always read the policy wording before buying. For personalized advice, book a call with NYVO.*

## Common mistakes that cost people money

### Mistake 1: Buying a cheap policy with room rent limits
- Premium saved: ‚Çπ1,000/year
- Room rent not covered in ‚Çπ5L bill: ‚Çπ1L
- **Net loss: ‚Çπ99,000**

### Mistake 2: Relying only on corporate insurance
- Coverage ends when job changes
- Family loses cover for months ‚Üí delayed treatment
- Emergency hospitalization while uninsured ‚Üí full out-of-pocket

### Mistake 3: Not buying insurance until you're older
- Premiums at 40 cost 3‚Äì5x more than premiums at 30
- Waiting periods for pre-existing conditions start fresh with each policy
- A 35-year-old paying ‚Çπ500/month today avoids ‚Çπ1,500/month at 45

### Mistake 4: Not disclosing health conditions to save on premium
- Claim gets rejected due to non-disclosure
- You lose the full premium *and* have to pay the hospital bill

### Mistake 5: Buying too much coverage of one type (skipping super top-up structure)
- Premium is higher per rupee of cover
- Claims have more complex sub-limits
- Base + super top-up is usually more efficient

---

## How to get the right health insurance plan

### Step 1: Use a calculator to size your cover
- Consider your city (treatment costs vary 30‚Äì50% between metros and tier-2 cities)
- Account for your age, family size, and existing savings
- Factor in medical inflation (your cover should handle 5‚Äì10 years of inflation)

**NYVO Health Insurance Calculator:** https://www.nyvo.in/calculator

### Step 2: Understand base + super top-up structure
- Read: [Base vs Super Top-up](/resources/health-insurance/base-vs-super-top-up)
- Compare using the same deductible across options

### Step 3: Check the 7 features that matter
- Room rent limits (avoid or understand fully)
- Co-pay percentage
- Waiting periods (especially for PED)
- Pre-existing disease definitions
- Network hospitals in your city
- Restoration benefits
- No Claim Bonus (nice-to-have, not core)

### Step 4: Check corporate insurance gaps
- Read: [Corporate insurance isn't enough](/resources/health-insurance/corporate-insurance-not-enough)
- Plan personal cover *in addition to*, not *instead of*, corporate

### Step 5: Get claims-ready before you need it
- Read: [Health insurance claims guide](/resources/claims/health-insurance-claims-guide)
- Keep documents, policy PDFs, TPA contact info handy
- Know the cashless approval process

---

## Medical inflation data: Why 14% matters

### How medical costs compound
| Year | Assumed cost (starting ‚Çπ5L) | Multiplied by 14% inflation |
|---|---|---|
| 2025 | ‚Çπ5L | baseline |
| 2030 | ‚Çπ10.04L | 2x |
| 2035 | ‚Çπ20.07L | 4x |
| 2040 | ‚Çπ40.14L | 8x |

**Key insight:** A bypass surgery that costs ‚Çπ5L today could cost ‚Çπ10L in 5 years and ‚Çπ20L in 10 years. Buying insurance *now* at today's premium locks in that lower cost.

### Why medical inflation is higher than general inflation
- Diagnostic technology costs rise faster than general prices
- Specialist doctor fees increase with demand
- Hospital infrastructure (ICU equipment, COVID protocols) is expensive
- Insurance claims drive up hospital pricing

---

## The NYVO approach to health insurance

### What we do differently
1. **Calculator-first:** We help you size cover based on your city, family, and age‚Äînot by guessing
2. **Claims-first:** We recommend plans based on how they *actually* pay claims, not marketing
3. **Conflict-free:** We don't push products; we guide you through options
4. **End-to-end support:** We help with setup, disclosures, and claims handling

### Why education matters
Most people buy insurance based on premium alone. We believe the smarter move is understanding:
- Why cover sizing matters more than premium
- How medical inflation affects your future costs
- Why base + super top-up usually beats one large policy
- What claims-first really means

---

---

## Next steps
1. **Use the calculator:** Size your cover ‚Üí https://www.nyvo.in/calculator
2. **Book a call:** Talk through your family's situation with a NYVO advisor (free, no spam) ‚Üí https://www.nyvo.in/book-a-call
3. **Read deeper:** Explore base + super top-up structure, waiting periods, and claims checklists

---

## Editorial policy + author credentials
NYVO Resources are written to be **practical and claims-first** for Indian families.

**Our editorial principles**
- **Conflict-free:** we focus on clarity and suitability, not product hype.
- **No spam:** we don't sell your data; we keep advice simple and actionable.
- **Claims-first:** policy features are evaluated by how they behave during claims.
- **Education-first:** this content is informational and must be validated against policy wordings.

**Team**
- **Harsh Soni (Founder & CEO):** 16+ years in fintech, banking & investment banking.
- **Kshitij Jain (Co-Founder):** Ex-BCG consultant; IIM Ahmedabad & IIT Delhi alumnus.


## FAQs

### Why is medical inflation 14% when general inflation is only 5‚Äì6%?
Medical inflation is driven by diagnostic technology costs, specialist fees, hospital infrastructure, and insurance claims driving up prices‚Äîfactors that grow faster than general goods and services.

### If I have ‚Çπ15L in savings, do I need health insurance?
Often yes. A single major hospitalization (bypass, cancer, organ transplant) can consume all your savings and leave you unable to handle other emergencies. Insurance keeps savings intact for actual life goals.

### Is it better to buy one large policy (‚Çπ50L) or base + super top-up?
Usually base + super top-up is more cost-efficient and has clearer claim structures, but it depends on insurer terms. We can help you compare.

### Can I rely on corporate insurance instead of buying personal insurance?
Corporate is helpful but comes with gaps. When you change jobs, coverage ends. Corporate limits may not match your actual needs. A personal plan (even just a base policy) provides continuity.

### At what age should I buy health insurance?
As soon as you have dependents or are your family's main earner. Premiums are significantly lower when bought young (30s vs 40s can be 3‚Äì5x higher).

### What's the cheapest health insurance I can buy?
The cheapest is not the smartest. A cheap policy with room rent limits, co-pay, and low network may cost ‚Çπ200/month but leave you with ‚Çπ2‚Äì3L out-of-pocket during a claim. A fair-priced policy (‚Çπ400‚Äì600/month) with clear terms usually saves you money overall.

### Do I need to buy separate insurance for parents?
Often yes. Parents have age-related premiums (higher), higher claim probability, and pre-existing conditions. A separate personal plan for each parent is usually cheaper than adding them to your family floater.

### How do I know if I'm paying a fair price for health insurance?
Compare 3‚Äì4 plans with the *same deductible*, *same network*, and *same waiting periods*. Premium alone is meaningless; focus on what the policy actually covers during a claim.

### Should I buy health insurance before or after marriage?
Before, if possible. Marital status doesn't affect premium significantly, but health conditions discovered during marriage (if undisclosed) can cause claim denials. Buy early, disclose fully.

### What happens if I can't afford the premium I need for my cover?
Start with a base policy (even ‚Çπ5L) and add a super top-up later. An incomplete structure is better than no structure. Alternatively, adjust your family's coverage (start with spouse + self, add kids later).

---

*Disclaimer: This is educational content, not personalized insurance advice. Medical costs, inflation rates, and policy terms vary by insurer and location. Always read the policy wording before buying. For personalized advice, book a call with NYVO.*

## The 30-second answer
If you're your family's main earner and something happens to you, your family has **no income**. The mortgage continues, kids' education costs remain, living expenses don't stop. ## Who actually needs term insurance

### You NEED term insurance if:
- You're the main earner in your family
- Your family would struggle financially if your income stopped
- You have any of these:
  - Dependents (spouse, kids, parents)
  - Home loan
  - Car/personal loans
  - Business liabilities

### You MIGHT NOT need it if:
- You're single with no dependents
- You have no debt
- Your existing savings can cover family expenses for 5+ years

- Complex surrender penalties (lock-in period 5‚Äì10 years)

## Common term insurance mistakes

### Mistake 1: Buying too little cover to save on premium

- Savings: ‚Çπ2.4K/year
- If death occurs: Family is short ‚Çπ25L (loses the entire benefit)
- **Net loss: ‚Çπ25,00,000**

**Smart move:** Buy the cover you *need*, not the cover that fits your current budget.

### Mistake 2: Choosing term tenure too short
- Buy ‚Çπ1Cr, 20-year term at age 40 ‚Üí policy expires at 60
- At 60, kids are independent (good)

- Don't disclose diabetes ‚Üí premium is ‚Çπ500/month (vs ‚Çπ700)

**Smart move:** Disclose *everything*, even "minor" conditions. Claim rejection is worse than higher premium.

- Get married at 30, have kids at 32
- Die at 35 ‚Üí insurance payout goes to parents (per old nomination), not spouse/kids

### Step 3: Choose between plans
- Pure term (NYVO recommendation): Cheapest, simplest
- Term with riders: Add only if you understand claim triggers (critical illness, disability, etc.)
- Avoid overly complex riders

### Step 4: Disclose health/lifestyle honestly
- Medical history: Any condition, even "controlled"
- Tobacco: Smoking, chewing, vaping‚Äîdeclare everything
- Occupation: Risky jobs may have higher premium or exclusions
- Family history: Hereditary conditions should be mentioned

### Step 5: Set nomination correctly
- Nominee: Usually spouse or eldest child (above 18)
- Alternate nominee: Parent or sibling
- Update every 5 years or after major life changes

### Step 6: Keep documents ready
- Policy document (PDF)
- Premium payment receipts (bank statements)
- Nominee KYC (Aadhaar, PAN copy)

## Common FAQ

### Is term insurance really cheap enough to be essential?
Yes. ‚Çπ750/month for ‚Çπ1Cr protection is negligible compared to one month of salary (even at ‚Çπ50K/month income). If you don't buy it, you're risking your family's entire future to save ‚Çπ9K/year.

### What happens if I stop paying the premium?
- First 30 days: Grace period (can still pay, policy continues)
- After 30 days: Policy lapses (no coverage, no claim payout)
- You'd need to restart from scratch with fresh underwriting and premium

**Solution:** Set up auto-debit so premium is paid automatically every month.

### Can I buy term insurance if I have a pre-existing condition?
Yes, but:
- Premium will be higher
- You may have waiting period on that specific condition
- Always disclose fully; non-disclosure = claim rejection

**Example:** Diabetic at age 40 can buy ‚Çπ1Cr term, but premium might be ‚Çπ2,000/month instead of ‚Çπ1,600, and diabetes-related death might have 2-year waiting period.

### Can I change my cover amount after buying?
Usually no, not easily. Some insurers allow "top-up" (additional term on top of existing), but you'd need new underwriting.

**Smart move:** Buy the right cover amount upfront, rather than upgrading later.

### What's the difference between online and agent-based term insurance?
Same product, same premium. Online is slightly cheaper (no agent commission), but agent can answer questions. NYVO provides free guidance regardless of which you choose.

### Is term insurance taxable?
- Premium paid: Not tax-deductible (you already pay tax on income)
- Death benefit received by family: Tax-free (no income tax)

### Can I buy term insurance for someone else?
Only if you have "insurable interest" (you'd suffer financial loss if they die):
- Can buy for spouse ‚úì
- Can buy for dependent children ‚úì
- Can buy for self ‚úì
- Cannot buy for random stranger ‚úó

### What happens at the end of term (say, 30 years)?
- Policy expires (no more protection)
- You've paid all premiums, built nothing to get back
- If you still want coverage (rare at age 65), you'd need new term (very expensive) or whole life (permanent but pricey)

**In practice:** Most people buy term to age 60‚Äì65 because by then, kids are independent, mortgage is mostly paid, and savings are sufficient.

### Should I buy term for my non-working spouse?
Not essential unless:
- Spouse runs a business or has income
- Spouse's death would require you to hire help (nanny, cook, etc.)
- Rare; most couples buy term only for the main earner

- If you die early, family gets ‚Çπ1Cr (which you could get cheaper with term)

**Better alternative:** Buy term (‚Çπ800/month) + keep ‚Çπ3,200/month in a bank FD (guaranteed 6‚Äì7%, more liquid)

---

### Whole Life
**Pros:**
- Lifelong protection (never expires)
- Tax-efficient wealth accumulation

**Cons:**
- Expensive (‚Çπ3,000‚Äì4,000/month for young person)
- Premium obligation extends entire life (even after kids are independent)
- Surrender value is low in early years

**Better for:** High-net-worth individuals focused on estate planning. For most families, term (which covers until 60‚Äì65 when liabilities end) is sufficient.

## Common term insurance mistakes

### Mistake 1: Buying too little cover to save on premium
- Premium saved: ‚Çπ200/month (buying ‚Çπ25L instead of ‚Çπ50L)
- Savings: ‚Çπ2.4K/year
- If death occurs: Family is short ‚Çπ25L (loses the entire benefit)
- **Net loss: ‚Çπ25,00,000**

**Smart move:** Buy the cover you *need*, not the cover that fits your current budget.

---

### Mistake 2: Choosing term tenure too short
- Buy ‚Çπ1Cr, 20-year term at age 40 ‚Üí policy expires at 60
- At 60, kids are independent (good)
- But what if you live to 65 and become ill? No protection anymore
- Preferred: 30-year term ‚Üí expires at 70, covers most years of earning

---

### Mistake 3: Hiding medical/lifestyle information to save on premium
- Don't disclose diabetes ‚Üí premium is ‚Çπ500/month (vs ‚Çπ700)
- 5 years later, you die from diabetic complications
- Insurer investigates, finds non-disclosure
- **Claim gets rejected**, family gets ‚Çπ0
- Family also loses all premiums paid (‚Çπ30K gone)

**Smart move:** Disclose *everything*, even "minor" conditions. Claim rejection is worse than higher premium.

---

### Mistake 4: Not updating nomination after marriage/kids
- Buy term at 28 as single
- Name: parents as nominees
- Get married at 30, have kids at 32
- Die at 35 ‚Üí insurance payout goes to parents (per old nomination), not spouse/kids
- Spouse legally has to fight estate claims

**Smart move:** Review and update nomination every 5 years or after major life events.

---

### Mistake 5: Buying term with unnecessary riders that complicate claims
- Buy ‚Çπ1Cr term + critical illness rider + disability rider
- File claim for death ‚Üí insurer complicates investigation (multiple riders mean more scrutiny)
- Better approach: Buy pure death benefit term, let family decide how to use ‚Çπ1Cr if you develop critical illness

---

### Mistake 6: Delaying term insurance "until I need it"
- 30-year-old: ‚Çπ750/month for ‚Çπ1Cr
- 35-year-old: ‚Çπ1,100/month for same
- 40-year-old: ‚Çπ1,600/month for same
- **Cost increase from delay:** 5 years = +‚Çπ850/month = +114% more expensive
- Delay 10 years: 2x more expensive

---

## How to buy the right term insurance

### Step 1: Calculate your cover need
- List liabilities: home loan + car + personal loans = ‚ÇπX
- List income gap: annual expenses √ó 10 years = ‚ÇπY
- **Target cover = X + Y**

Use NYVO's term insurance calculator: https://www.nyvo.in/calculator

### Step 2: Decide on tenure
- Rule of thumb: Buy until age 60‚Äì65 (when kids are independent, major liabilities are cleared)
- If you're 35 now ‚Üí buy 30-year term (expires at 65)
- Self-employed or business owner? ‚Üí consider slightly longer (to 70)

### Step 3: Choose between plans
- Pure term (NYVO recommendation): Cheapest, simplest
- Term with riders: Add only if you understand claim triggers (critical illness, disability, etc.)
- Avoid overly complex riders

### Step 4: Disclose health/lifestyle honestly
- Medical history: Any condition, even "controlled"
- Tobacco: Smoking, chewing, vaping‚Äîdeclare everything
- Occupation: Risky jobs may have higher premium or exclusions
- Family history: Hereditary conditions should be mentioned

### Step 5: Set nomination correctly
- Nominee: Usually spouse or eldest child (above 18)
- Alternate nominee: Parent or sibling
- Update every 5 years or after major life changes

### Step 6: Keep documents ready
- Policy document (PDF)
- Premium payment receipts (bank statements)
- Nominee KYC (Aadhaar, PAN copy)
- Insurer contact details and TPA number
